# init(type:shape:)

**Initializer**

Creates a physics body with the specified type and shape.

## Declaration

```swift
convenience init(type: SCNPhysicsBodyType, shape: SCNPhysicsShape?)
```

## Parameters

- **type**: A constant that determines how a body responds to forces and collisions. See [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNPhysicsBodyType].
- **shape**: A physics shape defining the volume of the body for collision detection purposes.

## Return Value

A new physics body object.

## Discussion

For the body to participate in collision detection or respond to forces, you must attach it to the [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNNode/physicsBody] property of an [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNNode] object in a scene.

If you pass `nil` for the shape parameter, SceneKit automatically creates a physics shape for the body when you attach it to a node, based on that node’s [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNNode/geometry] property. To create a physics shape that’s based on the geometries of a node and its hierarchy of children, or to control the level of detail in a physics shape, create the physics shape manually using an [doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNPhysicsShape] class method.



## Related Documentation

- **type**: A constant that determines how the physics body responds to forces and collisions.
- **physicsShape**: An object that defines the solid volume of the physics body for use in collision detection.

## Creating Physics Bodies

- **static()**: Creates a physics body that is unaffected by forces or collisions and that cannot move.
- **dynamic()**: Creates a physics body that can be affected by forces and collisions.
- **kinematic()**: Creates a physics body that is unaffected by forces or collisions but that can cause collisions affecting other bodies when moved.
